description.narrative:
This project focuses on program development leading to a 5 -year multi partner program in which African and Dutch investigative journalists jointly will develop media productions and publications concerning issues that matter (global issues of injustice).
Digital revolution has shaken the entire media world. This has led to uncertainty within the established order of journalism, but also to space created for new initiatives. This will mainly have to be done from within, by connecting to developments which are already going on, no matter at what early stage,
- The meaning of freelancers for Dutch media has considerably increased and became essential.Freelancers who want to survive, will have to specialize. Building their own networks (‘organizing know-how ‘) is an important condition (' Changing media landscape'); - Both the media and the individual journalists have a growing need for databases from reliablesources .
Despite the sometimes poor quality of the media in many African countries, the continent has a growing number of highly qualified journalists. This enables equal collaboration between African and Dutch journalists (see the report " White spots on the map' of Kees Schaepman and Bob van der Winden, on which this project is based). Based on these recommendations, the Stiching Medio has developed a project that focuses on a platform for intensive cooperation between journalists from the Netherlands and Africa. In 2014, 10 (pilot) exchanges will take place between Dutch (European) media. These include, amongst others, Stichting Worldcom, ZAM, FPU and African networks (Witzi University, Panos , FAIR ). On basis of these pilots, the Stiching Medio now has developed a project that aims on the exchange between participating journalists from the Netherlands (Europe) and African journalists. This project aims to systematize the experiences of the exchange partners, to come to an executable support program for such forms of cooperation, andfinally to create a network of partners. Besides, a global network on investigative journalism will be identified.
It can lead to a sustainable, specialized network for participants in co - productions. A concept note will be written which will be the basis of the multiannual program. In September 2014 all lessons learned from the pilots will be shared at a seminar in the Netherlands (in depth) and in November at a seminar in Johannesburg (University Witzi).
These seminars serve as an important step in the creation of this network. The "message" used at the seminar is "Cooperation is possible, although necessary barriers it will have to be conquered". In addition, specific solutions will be presented by the participants. The perspective of the action: "let one, two, many partnerships flourish". Ultimately, this should lead to an international media platform in which through working together, nuanced stories are published in the Netherlands and in Africa. This can lead to improvement of understanding, approach and policy/debate.

participating-org.narrative:
Mission and Vision of Medio foundation (Mission) Developing sustainable links between (media) organisations and practitioners in Europe and those in developing countries, through (vision) supporting exchange projects and meetings between those groups, including matchmaking, brokering and technical support where necessary to partners in the South.
The organization started in 1984 supporting aprint shop (for the blind and other disabled) in Nicaragua, followed by a print shop in El Salvador in 1990. In 1996 we supported aprint shop and several (starting) newspapers in Angola. In 2000 Medio implemented the ‘Comalapa’ project resulting in an on-line publication (Nicaragua). In 2001 we published the book ‘Sniffing Glue’ about street kids in Managua, Nicaragua, in support of Tesisfoundation from Nicaragua.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: no. of cases of demonstrably improved professionalism of southern media and citizen journalists (bloggers) (among others in gender sensitive fashion)
